turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Peanut butter and jelly.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: No, thanks.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: No, I mean Ricky. He's not interested in any of this stuff.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Well, this pate is rather...unusual.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Pate? What pate?  I didn't make any --  Oh, no, Clark. That's Buster's dog food.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Gee, I haven't laughed like that since -- since --  I really can't remember when.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Me neither...

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: So...how much longer do you think you'll be in Smallville --

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: You know, I was just thinking, Lana --  -- someone like you could do do really well in Metropolis --

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: I can never get a way from it.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Old ties are hard to cut.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: No. I mean, yes they are, but I was talking about that.  Wheat King. Bet your bottom dollar that's a Wheat King thresher.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: That's the biggest change in Smallville, you know. They've taken over this town. Everybody who isn't actually working for Wheat King -- like I do -- is out there --  on a Wheat King thresher.  Do you think I could do it? Do you?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Ride a thresher? Well, I don't know. Girls are trying just about everything now but --

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: No, what you said before, Could I make it in Metropolis? I've dreamed about it, sure, but I never really thought about it.  What would I do when I got there?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Call me.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Oh, I wouldn't want to -- I mean, I'd want to, but I wouldn't want to...be a nuisance to you.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: The dog's always doing that.  And the car's always doing that.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Can I help?

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: He really was!

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Well, aren't you excited?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Lana, I'm from Metropolis. I see Superman every day.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Gee, I always loved porch swings.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Me too. That's why I put this one up.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: No, well in this case I think I can speak for him.  I mean, I'm pretty close to him, you know.  Superman will be there on Wednesday.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Well, he's going to get the best home-cooked meal he's had in... in a long time. You tell Superman we think he's wonderful.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: I guess he misses a lot of dinners.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: But if you wouldn't mind settling for me --

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Anyday...

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Hi, Lois. Morning, Jimmy, you've got mustard on your lapel. Excuse me, Mr. White, I don't mean to interrupt but ---

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: Please, Kent, not now. I'm trying to put out a newspaper here.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Mr. White, please, I promised those people I'd get back to them by this morning. What do you think?

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: Look, I don't know, Kent. . . CLARK  Personally, I think it could be a terrific story!

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: I'm getting a cramp in my elbow from this.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Let me do it for you, Mr. White.

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: -- but you  deserve the vacation, Lois.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Oh. You're going away.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Uh...excuse me, folks...

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: Kent!

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mr. White, but I've got an errand to run.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Well...  Not quite like this.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: Mom and I do this all the time.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: Mr. Kent! Superman was here!

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: What!

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: Do you really know Superman?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: We get together sometimes.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: Mr. Kent, could I ask you something?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: Could you get me Superman's autograph?

turns.speaker: RICKY
turns.text: Hi. Mister Kent.  Guess who Mom's having dinner with tonight? Superman!

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Actually, that's why I stopped by. He's realy sorry, he wanted to make it, but then he...ran into a problem.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Anyway, the reunion's just the hook for the story. What it's really about is how the typical small town's changed in the last fifteen years. how do you like this a title: Can You Go Home Again ?

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Say!

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Take me, for instance. Going back to middle America after having become a Metropolis sophisticate --

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: So, Mr. White? Can I go ahead and make my travel arrangements?

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Exactly what I was about to ask about me.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: You're the best, Lois.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: I'd better be. Suddenly I've got competition to keep up with.  Your high school reunion article. I though it was terrific. And fascinating.  Especially about the girl back home.  I'll tell you what, Clark, I'll take you to lunch and you can tell me all about it.

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Gee, I'm sorry, Lois. But I've already got a lunch date. With Mr. White's new secretary.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: It's practically an American ritual, Mr. White! Isn't that so, Jimmy?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I wouldn't know Mr. Kent. Most of the people I went to high school with are still in high school.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: But my Uncle Al, on my father's side, he won't eat her stuffing, he says it should be cooked on the outside of the turkey and she puts the stuffing inside the turkey. So my mother told my Aunt Ellen . . . Aunt Ellen's my father's half-sister, I told you that, right?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: Mmmmm . . .

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: The thing is though, my cousin Arnold, Aunt Rosey's Arnold this is, he got mad when Uncle Al insulted his mother's stuffing, so now the problem is --

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Wow, what a beautiful sunrise!

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: At one o'clock in the morning?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Keep talking to that state trooper so he doesn't notice where I'm going, okay?

turns.speaker: CLARK
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: You know what Mr. White said. A photographer always goes after a story.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Name?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Gus Gorman.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Ah yes, August Gorman. Have you looked for work this week, Mr. Gorman?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: What kind?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Kitchen. . . Technician

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Dishwasher? Any luck?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Nope, but --

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Mr. Gorman, according to our records you have been unemployed for 36 weeks.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Thirty-five.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Not counting this week.  You secured employment last June as a messenger and were discharged after one day for. . .

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: They said I lost it on the subway, but it ain't the truth! It was a pickpocket took it!

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: A television set?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Well, it was one of them little bitty two-inch screen Japanese jobs.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: The only other employment you found was in a fast-food joint--  -- which lasted. . . 28 minutes! Well! That's some kind of record. Talk about fast!

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Man, them people was crazy! How they 'spect you to learn all that jive on the first day? "Hold the pickle! Hold the lettuce! Extra onions! Special sauce! No special sauce!" Ain't nobody found no meat inside that glop yet.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Mr. Gorman, the city of Metropolis is generous to a fault, but. . .

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I know, I'm the fault.

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: Thirty-six weeks of chronic unemployment, thirty-six weeks of living off the taxes of hard-working citizens. Do you know what you are?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Don't call me a bum! I ain't no bum!

turns.speaker: CLERK
turns.text: You are, I was about to say, no longer eligible.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: What about this week's check?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Sonofagun! Look at this here!

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: First paycheck?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: First rip-off, man! Supposed to be 225 bucks a week! You know what this sucker says?? $143.80!  Federal tax! State tax! Social Security tax!

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: That's so you're still getting some money when you hit 65.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I ain't gonna live that long on $143.80! I want it now, man, while I'm still young and cool.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Actually, it's probably more like $143.80 and one-half cent.  There's always fractions over in a big corporation, but they round it down to the lowest whole number.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: What'm I gonna do with half a cent? Buy me a thoroughbred cockroach?  Everybody loses them fractions?

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: They don't actually lose 'em. You can't lose what you never got.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Who gets it, the company?

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: No, not really. They can't be bothered collecting half a cent from your paycheck anymore than you could.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: So where is all them half-centses?

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: They're just . . . floating around out there. The computer knows where.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: How many sugars?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: One.  And a half.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Quittin' time, Gus. Comin'?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Uh . . . no, man. I got some work to finish up here.

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Workin' overtime? What are you doin', buddy, looking for a raise?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Yeah. A raise . .

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: Gus?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Say what?

turns.speaker: FRED
turns.text: The boss wants to see you.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Say who?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Please, Mr. Webster, you're a great humanitarian. Ain't you heard what it's like in them jails? You send an innocent boy in and he gets thrown in with killers and robbers and rapers and raper killer and robber rapers and...

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Mr. Gorman, just answer me one question...

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: You've been a naughty boy haven't you?  C'mon now, admit it, you were kinda naughty.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Uh...yeah. I didn't think of it that way exactly, but...

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Say, fella, I understand. I can -- what do the kids say these days -- "dig where you're comin' from."  You want to be rich, right?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Uh...

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Now me, I was born rich. I've never worn the same pair of socks twice.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Yeah? What do you do with 'em?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: I believe they're laundered and sent to some charitable institution. I don't know what the heck they do with 'em. Maybe they use them for dust rags, or pen wipers...

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Or socks.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Yes! That never occurred to me.  Her ya go, buddy, single-malt.  Gus, my friend, you're a genius. Okay, a naughty genius, but hell, nobody's perfect.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: 'Cause I know about getting' them half-centses?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Gus, Webco, the Webster industrial complex, is a family-owned cartel. A little magnesium here, a little zinc there. Some railroads here, some farm machinery there. You follow?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I'm tryin' to.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Gus, do you know what I want now? I want coffee!

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Black or regular?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: I don't think you understand.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Man, what is this?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Plants. Plants always make an office cozier.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Under different company names. I control the price of coffee beans in Brazil. The price in Venezuela. Java, South Korea, North Korea, the Aleutian Islands, Guam, Bolivia, and the Republic of Gabon!

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Decaffeinated too?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: But y'see, chum, the problem I got is that one country just won't play ball with me.  You know how that can just bug a guy, don't you?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Which country?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Columbia.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Columbia.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Columbia's got two major exports and one of them's coffee.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Wipe 'em out?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Destroy the entire Colombian coffee crop down to the last bean.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: But Mr. Webster...you're doin' okay with Brazil and them other places. What's wrong with just one little old country doin' their own thing?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: A very wise man once said...I think it was Attila the Hun... "It's not enough that I succeed. Everyone else must fail."  And you are going to do it for me.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Me? How?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Gus, tell me, have you ever heard of Vulcan?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: That what they call you?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: How do you do that?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Like everything else in the 20th century, Gus. You push buttons.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Always making yourself beautiful for me, aren't you?  So, Gus, can you make Vulcan do what I want it to? You didn't answer me, pal.  Did you hear about that prison riot last week? It seems they were complaining about rats in the cells...

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Yeah, yeah, I can do it.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: First question got to be "Where."

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Not "What." Don't need a genius to figure out "what." Need a genius to figure out "where."  He says I'm a genius, your don --  Brother! Bubba! Your Bubba!  See, if y'all don't want them to trace it back, you got to punch this in from someplace nobody'd ever think off. Some little rinky- dink operation with a little mickey- mouse computer. ROSS It's got to be someplace you can sneak into.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Hey, boss.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Just the man I wanted to see!

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Turn on the T.V.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: I did. isn't it neat-o?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Uh...what channel were you watching?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: What are you talking about, fella?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: It ain't. It's nowhere. It blew up. That's how come they shipped the dude to Earth when he was a baby.  well. I know some stuff too, y'all.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Wait a second. Astronomers know where the planet used to be, right? And you know what happens when a planet explodes? Debris. Pieces floating in space.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Just hold on a minute. I have been doin' some thinkin'

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: God, that's what I keep you for.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: That's what I been thinkin' about. How you been keepin' me.  I ain't getting' nothing outta this gig.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Gus, if there's anything I hate, it's greed.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Greed!  Let me tell you something---

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: He sure wasn't actin' bad and nasty that day in Smallville. Man, he was so full of niceness I was startin' to feel funny about layin' that chunk of...

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: KRYPTONITE!

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Every oil tanker and super- tanker and super-duper-tanker in the ocean is controlled. totally, by computers. Computers to tell them where to go, how much oil to take on, where to deliver it.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: They ain't got captains?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Yes, but they don't really need them. it's just a throw- back to some sentimental sea- faring baloney.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: And do nothing. Just sit there.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Then how's all the people gonna get their oil?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: You catch on fast, old buddy.  Tell him about the pumps. I know how you love the part about the pumps.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: And then shut down the pipe lines.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Pumps stop pumping oil. Pipe lines stop pipin' oil. Tankers stop deliverin' oil. Man, this is high stakes.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Thanks, kiddo. now, listen, this part's important. I want you to program one special command into all these systems. Tell them these orders are irreversible, so it'll be impossible for anybody to switch them back. Can you do that, pal?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Lookit, you're getting' what you want all the time. it ain't right that I don't get somethin'! I never get somethin'!

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: I knew it, I knew it, go be nice to people and they think they can ask for the moon!

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: The moon! Listen, man, when I was a little bitty kid all my friends got them electric trains for Christmas. My mama didn't have barely enough to pay the electric bill, let alone buy me no train set.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Now...when do I get a taste?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: I should think a taste of freedom is enough, don't you? Or would you prefer jail?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Don't lay that jail number on me no more. You need me out here doin' stuff for you more'n sitten' in no jail doin' nothin' for nobody.  'Sides, I be known' some heavy stuff about you now. You don't want em spillin' the coffee beans.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Is this blackmail?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Don't be getting' racist with me, man.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Is this whitemail?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Fair's fair.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: What do you want?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: A waste-basket? GUS Those are plans.  Blueprints.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: A computer.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: We've already got some.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Not like this one you ain't. Nobody in the world got one like this 'cause it don't exist yet. We got to build it.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: You designed it?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I invented it, man. In my head. It's a stone killer-diller get-down get-it-on and twice-on-Sunday super mutha computer.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: What will it do?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Everything.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: What will it get me?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Anything.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Tell me more...

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Yeah? How's it look?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: It looks wonderful. it is wonderful, let's face it.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I told you it wasn't no jive.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Gus, it seems we are talking state-of-the-art technology here. We are talking unlimited power. We are talking "get-down hot-cha daddy-o" whatever you called it.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Stone mutha.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Exactly. Stoned mother.

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: But a machine this powerful is going to make powerful enemies. People who will want to destroy it.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Ain't nobody gonna mess with my machine! I'll...I'll... what will I do?  I'll build in a counter-punch! Anything attacks it gets counter- attacked! And wiped out!

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Can you do that?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Yeah, sure.  Ain't nobody gonna stomp my electric train...

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Remember, Gus. A machine doesn't want anything except to keep on being a machine. You've got to make sure it can figure out how to beat any opponent.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Man, all it got to do is find their weak spot.  You bet on the machine in any fight you name, you gonna win your bet.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: You want to mess with Superman?

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Can't wait, pal, can't wait.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Awright. I got me my electric train, mama. I finally got --  Hey, what y'all doin' up there?!

turns.speaker: ROSS
turns.text: Join the party, genius! Come on up!

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: How you doing down there?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Don't make me talk, please. I got enough problems just hangin' on.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Hey, you're perfectly safe.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I ain't about to argue with you.  What's gonna happen to them three? Ross the boss and those ladies?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: That's up to the judge, Gus. It's not your problem anymore.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Watch out for them air pockets!

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: No, we're just going down.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: We gonna crash?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: I never crash, Gus. That'd be embarrassing.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: We back in Metropolis?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: No...I just have a little stop to make.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Whatcha wanna stop here for?  Not that I ain't glad to be on the ground, y'understand.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Just a second.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Thanks.  Let's go

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I was afraid you'd say that.  Hey, is there a bus station around here?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Suit yourself, Gus.  Say, does your boss use a computer in this operation?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Hey listen, I didn't know your mama was comin' by...

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Sister! I'm his sister!

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: Through the telephone line terminal, that ain't nothin'.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Oh Bubba, think of the possibilities.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: What she call you?

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: You will command the tankers to sail toward a 50-mile area in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean.

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: And do what?

turns.speaker: GUS
turns.text: I know, by computers.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Will you stop interrupting ?!  You will command the pumps to stop pumping.

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: Who is she?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Her name's Lorelei Ambrosia. She's Webster's Girl Friday.

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: Who's the other woman?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: That's his sister. Vera Webster.

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: You're amazing, Olsen. A boring banquet and you bring back 3,000 boring pictures. Then Superman puts out a fire on Third Avenue this morning and you stand there and watch the whole thing and you don't take one picture!!

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: I didn't have my camera with me.

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: A photographer eats with his camera, A Photographer sleeps with his camera --

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: All right, Kent. I just hope you know what you're doing. If you really think Smallville is your big chance, go for it.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: What about me?

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: What about you?

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: A story like this cries out for great human interest pictures.  The big dance! The Homecoming Game! Mr. Kent posing next to his old locker!

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: Why do I have to do this?

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: You! You're lucky I didn't fire you. I get a chance at exclusive on-the-spot pictures of the biggest forest fire in history and what does he come back with??? A broken leg and twelve melted rolls of film.

turns.speaker: JIMMY
turns.text: It was hot!

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Ricky?  Where...what...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: I'd wash that out with some iodine...  Okay, Mercurochrome.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Thank ...you.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Anytime.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Oh. I'm Lana Lang. This is Ricky.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: We've already met.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: And this is...  ...Clark.  My friend is around here somewhere, I'll just look for...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: I'm sorry, I'm in a real hurry.  See you around, pal.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: You know, I really wasn't expecting all this.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Well...I guess they did get a little carried away.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: He was asleep before his head hit the pillow.  Well, this was only the biggest day of his life. I really don't know how to thank you.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: You just did, with that great dinner.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: There's no rush.

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: But the bridge...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Hey, Don't I always get there in time?  Come on, relax.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: It's hard to believe... a great looking girl like you all alone like this. As she glances up at him, she is first flustered, then flattered, then...finally...just realistic:

turns.speaker: LANA
turns.text: Listen, are you sure you shouldn't do something about the bridge?

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: The bridge...?  I'd better get going!

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: The picture looks blurry.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: The picture's fine. That's the way she looks in real life.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: What terrific story?

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: Kent's been invited to his high-school class reunion.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Whoopee.

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: Hey, I'd definitely shoot color on that one, Jimmy. It'd be a crime to just use black and white.

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: Okay, Kent, call your people and tell them the Prodigal Son is coming home. FAVORING CLARK -- Happy now, he turns to leave the office. SHOT LOSES PERRY but we continue to hear his voice, o.s.

turns.speaker: PERRY
turns.text: Lois, I've got to hand it to you. You're amazing. Who else could manage to turn a three-week tropical vacation into a front page story that's going to blow the lid off government corruption in the Caribbean?

turns.speaker: LOIS
turns.text: I just knew I was onto something when that taxi driver kidnapped me.

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: I thought you'd never get here.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Hey, don't expect me to save you. Because I don't do that anymore.

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: Don't worry. I'm long past saving.

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: Well, don't let me keep you from anything.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: I'm in no rush.  So what do you have in mind?

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: Lots of things...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Tell me.

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: I'll do more than tell you. I'll show you, back at my place. If you'll just do me one little favor first.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: Okay, what is it? You want a ride?

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: Never.  I get air-sick. You wouldn't like that.

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: No, I don't think I would. So... then what can I do for you?

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: It isn't much, really, you see, there's this little boat. Well, not so little, really. And it's not going where it's supposed to go and...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: I don't know you, lady.

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: But the other night...

turns.speaker: SUPERMAN
turns.text: That wasn't me. That guy's gone.  And you're next Webster.

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: Ross, honey, it's time for your massage...

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Bubba, does this woman have the right to burst in without knocking...!

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: If you don't mind, we are trying to hold a meeting here!

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: Why don't you hold your breath, instead? Maybe you'll turn blue. On you that'd be an improvement.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Why stop at coffee!  A cup of coffee gets the world off to work in the morning, but what keeps the world working?

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: Diet soda?

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Energy! And when they say "Energy" what do they mean? Nuclear? too dangerous. Solar?? Too underdeveloped.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: How would you know?

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: Hey, I know a lot of things!

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: So I understand from the graffiti I've seen.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: "At a special session of the General Assembly, 178 countries voted to censure Superman. With only Columbia abstaining." ROSS That fella's becoming a public menace.

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: And he use to be such a sweetie pie! What's wrong with him the last two weeks?

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: I can't see anything.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Turn on the light.

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: Where's the light switch?

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Where do you usually find a light switch?

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Come on, will you?  We've got to get ready before he gets here.

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: Gus?

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Superman. The boy you left behind.

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: You! Activate circuits 29 through W7 and start Full Power Coordinates on Exterior Defensive Systems:

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: In other words, push this red button.

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: Oh, Superman!

turns.speaker: VERA
turns.text: Cut the mush, Lorelei. He's after our skin!

turns.speaker: LORELEI
turns.text: He can have mine. Anytime.
